messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Of course error messages should be localized. These are shown to the end
> user and are part of the user interface, just like menu items, window
> titles, and other parts of the user interface. However, exception detail
> messages make extremely poor error messages. It's important to
> distinguish between these in a well-designed application, even if you're
> only ever going to ship the app in a single language.

Good exceptions should have some key features:

1) They should be identifiable - you should know that a given exception has
been caused by a particular problem.

2) They should be informative - that is, they should have the information
about what caused the problem.

These, curiously enough, can be used very easily to create good error
messages. The simple way is to have a key on the exception for a resource
bundle, which lets you look up a message pattern, which you then use to
create an error message with the data in the exception. (There are, of
course, other ways to do this, and not all exceptions should result in
error messages being presented to huamns, anyway)

If you use this approach, it is important to ensure in your tests that you
construct Exceptions with sufficent information.

Robert.
